Tax_Score: Excellent – NHR regime is one of Europe's best
Tax_Benefits_Premium: NHR (Non-Habitual Resident): 0-20% on qualifying foreign income for 10 years. Flat €7,500/year option. Pension income: 10% flat.
Special_Regime_Name: NHR – Non-Habitual Resident Regime (now NHR 2.0 targeting tech/science)
Flat_Tax_Available: Yes – NHR regime effectively creates flat rate
Tax_Treaty_Countries: UK, USA, Germany, France, Brazil, Canada, China, India + 80 others
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Freelancers, remote employees, passive income, pensions
Premium_Insights: NHR 2.0 (IFICI) now targets tech workers, researchers, startup founders with 20% flat rate. Original NHR closed to new applicants 2024 but grandfathered. 183 days required for tax residency. Best structure: D8 visa + NHR application within first tax year.

Tax_Score: Poor – high tax, world-class infrastructure tradeoff
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Research & development tax credits. Startup equity programs. No special nomad regime.
Special_Regime_Name: Standard German Income Tax (no special regime)
Premium_Insights: Germany has no special tax regime for nomads/expats. Effective rate ~35-45% depending on income. However world-class infrastructure, social security, and healthcare. Freelancers (Freiberufler) can deduct significant business expenses. Best suited for established high earners who value stability over tax optimization.

Tax_Score: Excellent – Zivno lump-sum deduction creates very low effective rate
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Sole trader (OSVČ) can deduct 60% of income as lump-sum expenses. Effective tax rate 11-18% for most freelancers.
Flat_Tax_Available: Yes – 15% flat on profit after 60% deduction
Social_Security_Applicable: Yes – ~29.2% social + ~13.5% health on assessed base (reduced with paušál)
Premium_Insights: Paušální výdaje (lump-sum deduction): declare 60% of gross as expenses automatically without receipts, taxed only on 40% of income. Example: €30k income → taxed on €12k → ~€1,800 income tax. Social/health contributions calculated on minimum base initially. Highly efficient for freelancers.

Tax_Score: Excellent – 15% flat, lowest in EU
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 15% flat personal income tax – lowest in EU. Small business tax (KATA) for sole traders: flat €230/month covers all tax and contributions.
Special_Regime_Name: KATA – Kisadózó Vállalkozások Tételes Adója (flat monthly tax for micro-businesses)
Social_Security_Applicable: Included in KATA flat monthly payment
Premium_Insights: KATA regime: ~€230/month flat payment covers all taxes and social contributions for income up to ~€15k/year. Above that, 15% income tax applies. Very predictable and simple. White Card requires not working for Hungarian employers. Combined: low cost + low tax = exceptional net income efficiency.

Tax_Score: Excellent – 0% corporate tax on reinvested profits
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 0% corporate income tax on undistributed/reinvested profits. 20% only on dividends when distributed. e-Residency enables running EU company from anywhere.
Special_Regime_Name: Estonian 0% Corporate Tax on Reinvested Profits
Flat_Tax_Available: Yes – 20% flat only on distributed profits
Social_Security_Applicable: Yes – 33% employer social tax (if paying salary)
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Company owners (OÜ), e-residents running Estonian companies
Premium_Insights: Most unique in Europe: 0% corporate tax as long as profits stay in company. Only taxed when distributed as dividends (20%). e-Residency allows non-residents to run Estonian EU company remotely – pay Estonian tax. Personal income tax 20% flat. Extremely digital: 99% of government services online. Best for: company owners reinvesting profits, those wanting EU company structure.

Tax_Score: Good
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Beckham Law: 24% flat tax for 6 years.
Premium_Insights: Same Spanish framework. Valencia Comunitat Valenciana has moderate regional income tax additions. Beckham Law same conditions. More relaxed application environment.

Tax_Score: Excellent – same NHR as Lisbon
Tax_Benefits_Premium: NHR / NHR 2.0 (IFICI): 20% flat on qualifying income for 10 years.
Premium_Insights: Identical tax framework to Lisbon. Lower cost of living means more of your income stays. NHR 2.0 specifically targets innovation and tech workers.

Tax_Score: Excellent – 50% income tax exemption for 7 years
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 50% income tax exemption for new tax residents for 7 years (Law 4172/2013 Art.5C). Alternative: €100k flat annual tax for non-doms.
Special_Regime_Name: Article 5C – 50% Tax Exemption for New Residents
Employment_Type_Eligibility: New tax residents not previously resident in Greece for 5 of last 6 years
Premium_Insights: 50% exemption requires not having been Greek tax resident in 5 of last 6 years + maintaining Greek tax residency 2+ years. Applies to employment and business income. Non-dom €100k flat tax applies to worldwide income regardless of amount – best for very high earners. Both require 183+ days in Greece.

Tax_Score: Good – same Polish Ryczałt framework
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Ryczałt lump-sum: 8.5-12% on gross revenue. Same as Warsaw.
Premium_Insights: Same Polish tax framework as Warsaw at lower living cost. Better net income efficiency. IT freelancers particularly well-served.

Tax_Score: Excellent – 0% income tax while on DNV
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Full income tax exemption while on Croatian Digital Nomad Visa. DNV holders are not considered Croatian tax residents.
Social_Security_Applicable: No – DNV holders not in Croatian social system
Tax_Treaty_Countries: N/A for DNV holders (not tax resident)
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Non-EU citizens on Croatian DNV working for non-Croatian employers
Premium_Insights: Unique situation: DNV holders pay zero Croatian income tax and are explicitly not treated as tax residents. Continue paying taxes in home country or use existing tax structure. Cannot renew DNV – must exit 6 months before reapplying. Best for: nomads with existing low-tax structures wanting EU Schengen year.

Tax_Score: Excellent – 10% flat, lowest in EU
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 10% flat personal income tax. 10% corporate tax. EOOD (single-member LLC): simple 10% on profit.
Social_Security_Applicable: Yes – ~24.7% total but on minimum base option for self-employed
Premium_Insights: Flat 10% on everything is Europe's simplest and most competitive rate. Self-employed can declare minimum social security base (€380/month in 2024) keeping social contributions very low. EOOD company formation in 2-3 days, €1 minimum capital. Non-Schengen EU but Schengen accession underway. Best for: tax efficiency seekers in EU.

Tax_Score: Excellent – 1-3% micro-enterprise tax on revenue
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Micro-enterprise tax: 1% of gross revenue (under 500k EUR). PFA (sole trader): 10% flat on net profit.
Premium_Insights: Micro-enterprise (SRL) paying 1% on revenue up to €500k is exceptionally efficient for service businesses. PFA (sole trader) pays 10% income tax. Social contributions (CAS+CASS) ~€2,500/year capped. Non-Schengen EU but Schengen accession underway. Low cost + low tax = strong nomad value proposition.

Tax_Score: Exceptional – Virtual Zone 0% on foreign income
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Virtual Zone company: 0% income tax on IT/tech services delivered outside Georgia. Individual entrepreneur (IE): 1% tax on foreign-sourced income under ~€155k/year.
Special_Regime_Name: Virtual Zone Entity + Individual Entrepreneur (IE) Regime
Social_Security_Applicable: No mandatory social security for non-residents / IE
Tax_Treaty_Countries: Limited – Germany, France, Netherlands, China + ~56 others
Employment_Type_Eligibility: IT/tech freelancers (Virtual Zone), all freelancers (IE), remote workers
Premium_Insights: Most tax-efficient non-EU option in Europe. Virtual Zone: register Georgian company, provide IT services to non-Georgian clients, pay 0% income tax. IE status: 1% tax on income up to 500k GEL (~€155k). Open bank account in 1 day. No social security for non-residents. Visa-free 1 year for most nationalities. Must actually be in Georgia.

Tax_Score: Excellent – 10% flat + freelancer lump-sum
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 10% flat income tax. Paušalno oporezivanje (flat tax for freelancers): fixed quarterly payments based on earnings bracket, often €100-500/quarter total.
Special_Regime_Name: Paušalno oporezivanje – Serbian Freelancer Flat Tax
Flat_Tax_Available: Yes – 10% flat or fixed quarterly paušal
Social_Security_Applicable: Yes – ~36% total but on minimum base for paušal
Premium_Insights: Paušal regime allows freelancers to pay a fixed quarterly amount covering income tax AND social contributions – often €150-400/quarter total depending on income bracket. Extremely simple. 10% corporate tax. Serbia has become a major nomad hub partly due to this tax efficiency. Best for: freelancers wanting predictable ultra-low tax costs.

Tax_Score: Good – startup and fintech incentives strong
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Small partnership (MB): 15% tax on profit (no audit required). Startup visa and sandbox regime for fintech.
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Self-employed, small business owners, tech workers
Premium_Insights: MB (small partnership) is a unique Lithuanian structure: simple setup, 15% tax on profits, no audit obligation. Post-Brexit fintech hub with Bank of Lithuania as progressive regulator. Strong blockchain/fintech ecosystem. Best for: fintech founders, self-employed wanting simple low-tax EU structure.

Tax_Score: Good – 0% corporate on reinvested profits (same as Estonia)
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Latvia adopted same Estonian-style 0% corporate tax on reinvested profits in 2018.
Special_Regime_Name: 0% Corporate Tax on Reinvested Profits (Latvian model)
Premium_Insights: Latvia copied Estonia's reinvestment model – 0% corporate on retained profits, 20% on distribution. Microenterprise tax available: flat 25% covering all taxes for small businesses. Declining population – government actively encouraging skilled immigration. Good EU Schengen base at lower cost than Tallinn.

Tax_Score: Good – lump-sum tax option for freelancers
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Ryczałt (lump-sum tax): 8.5-12% on gross revenue for IT/software professionals. No expense deductions needed.
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Self-employed sole traders (JDG), especially IT professionals
Premium_Insights: Ryczałt at 8.5% is excellent for IT/software (12% for higher-value services). No need to track expenses. ZUS social contributions are a significant fixed cost (~€300-500/month) especially in early years. After 2 years ZUS drops to regular rate. Most efficient for IT freelancers earning €3k+/month.

Tax_Score: Poor for nomads – researcher/expat scheme partial relief
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Researcher and key employee scheme: 32.84% flat tax for 7 years for qualifying new residents.
Social_Security_Applicable: Minimal – Denmark has very low social contributions (included in high income tax)
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Employees earning minimum ~€75k/year via Danish employer
Premium_Insights: Forskerordningen requires: Danish employer, minimum salary ~€75k/year, not previously Danish tax resident. 32.84% flat for 7 years is very attractive vs standard 55%. Not available for self-employed/freelancers. Best for: high-earning employees with Danish company offer.

Tax_Score: Poor for nomads – expert tax relief partial
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Expertskatt (Expert Tax Relief): 25% of salary tax-free for 5 years for qualifying experts.
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Employees earning 2x Swedish average (~€80k+) via Swedish employer
Premium_Insights: Expertskatt: 25% of gross salary exempt from Swedish tax for 5 years. Requires Swedish employer, high salary, and application within 3 months of arrival. Effective rate ~38% vs standard 52%. Not for freelancers. Best for: high-earning tech workers with Swedish employer offer.

Tax_Score: Poor for nomads – high tax, no special regime
Tax_Benefits_Premium: EIS/SEIS startup investment relief. No special nomad/expat regime.
Special_Regime_Name: Standard UK Income Tax (Scottish rates slightly higher)
Premium_Insights: Scotland sets its own income tax rates – slightly higher than rest of UK at top bands. No special expat/nomad regime post-Brexit. Non-Schengen Non-EU. UK Statutory Residence Test (SRT) for determining tax residency is complex. Best for: UK citizens, employed workers with UK employer offer.

Tax_Score: Moderate – corporate 12.5% is key; personal high
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Irish holding company: 12.5% corporate tax. SARP (Special Assignee Relief Programme): 30% income relief for qualifying assignees.
Flat_Tax_Available: No – SARP is partial relief only
Premium_Insights: 12.5% corporate is the headline – used by Google, Apple, Meta for EU structures. Personal income tax 40-52% (including USC/PRSI) is high. SARP: 30% relief on salary above €75k for qualifying assignees. Non-Schengen EU means different travel access. Best for: business owners using Irish holding structure, multinationals.

Tax_Score: Poor for nomads – same as Berlin, no special regime
Tax_Benefits_Premium: R&D tax credits available. Bavaria state has no additional income tax deductions beyond standard.
Premium_Insights: Same German tax framework as Berlin. No Bavarian-specific advantages. High earning potential from Munich tech/engineering sector partially offsets high tax. Freelancers can deduct significant business expenses reducing effective rate. Best for: established professionals with German clients/employers.

Tax_Score: Poor for nomads – high tax, no special regime
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Research premium (14% of R&D spend). Startup incentives. No special nomad/expat tax regime.
Special_Regime_Name: Standard Austrian Progressive Tax (no special nomad regime)
Premium_Insights: No special expat/nomad tax regime. Progressive up to 55%. However quality of life is consistently #1 globally (Mercer). Best for EU citizens prioritizing lifestyle over tax optimization. Gewerbeschein (business license) for EU self-employed is simple and cheap.

Tax_Score: Good
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Beckham Law + Andalusia regional tax reductions.
Premium_Insights: Andalusia region has lower regional income tax rates than Catalonia (Barcelona). Effective burden lower than Barcelona for same income. Growing Google-anchored tech scene creating employer ecosystem.

Tax_Score: Moderate – auto-entrepreneur attractive for small income; Monaco proximity
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Auto-entrepreneur: simplified regime, flat % social contributions (~22-25%), no VAT under threshold. Monaco proximity: 0% income tax (20 min away).
Flat_Tax_Available: No formal flat – auto-entrepreneur simplifies contributions
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Auto-entrepreneur for small businesses; employed via Talent Passport
Premium_Insights: Auto-entrepreneur (micro-enterprise) best for income under €77k services: pay ~22% social contributions, progressive income tax on top. Monaco (20 min from Nice) has 0% income tax for residents – requires Monaco residency (expensive – €3k+/month housing minimum). Côte d'Azur lifestyle with Monaco optionality is unique. Best for: high earners considering Monaco residency, lifestyle nomads.

Tax_Score: Excellent rate, poor infrastructure
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 10% flat income tax. 10% corporate tax. Extremely low rates.
Social_Security_Applicable: Yes – ~31% total (high relative to income tax)
Premium_Insights: Impressive 10% flat rate but social security contributions are high (~31%). Complex administrative system with entity (Federation vs RS) differences. Non-EU, no Schengen. Best for ultra-budget nomads accepting administrative complexity for extremely low cost base.

Tax_Score: Good – flat low tax, non-EU simplicity
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 15% flat personal income tax. 15% corporate tax. Simple tax system.
Tax_Treaty_Countries: Limited – Italy, Germany, Hungary, Belgium + ~20 others
Premium_Insights: Simple flat 15% system. EU candidate country – expect harmonization in coming years. Very low cost means even at 15% take-home is high in real terms. Best for: budget nomads comfortable outside EU/Schengen, those wanting low-tax non-EU base.

Tax_Score: Excellent – same Czech Zivno benefits
Tax_Benefits_Premium: OSVČ 60% lump-sum deduction same as Prague.
Premium_Insights: Same Czech tax benefits as Prague at 25-30% lower cost of living. Better net efficiency than Prague for same income.

Tax_Score: Good
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Ryczałt lump-sum same as Poland-wide.
Premium_Insights: Polish coastal city. Same Ryczałt framework. Slightly higher living costs than Krakow/Wroclaw but Baltic lifestyle premium.

Tax_Score: Moderate – normalized rate for self-employed
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Self-employed normirani odhodki: 80% expense deduction bringing effective rate to ~9.6% for up to €50k income.
Premium_Insights: Normirani odhodki deduct 80% of income for sole traders – effective income tax rate is ~9.6% on gross revenue up to €50k. Above €50k normal progressive rates apply. Social contributions ~€350/month. Best structure: Slovenian s.p. (sole proprietorship) using normirani regime.

Tax_Score: Excellent – same micro-enterprise as Bucharest
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Same Romanian micro-enterprise 1% tax. Same PFA 10% flat.
Premium_Insights: Same tax as Bucharest. Cluj is Romania's tech capital – better ecosystem for tech nomads. Slightly higher cost than Bucharest but still very affordable. Best Romanian city for tech workers.

Tax_Score: Good – Ryczałt available
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Ryczałt lump-sum tax option same as rest of Poland.
Premium_Insights: Same framework as Warsaw/Krakow. Lower cost of living improves net position further.

Tax_Score: Good
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Beckham Law + Andalusia regional reductions.
Premium_Insights: Same Andalusia framework. Summer heat (40°C+) limits year-round viability. Best as seasonal base.

Tax_Score: Good – Andalusia low regional rates
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Beckham Law + Andalusia regional reductions.
Premium_Insights: Cheapest Spanish DNV-eligible city. Same tax framework as Malaga. Best cost:tax ratio in Spain.

Tax_Score: Poor for most; excellent for very high earners
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Flat €100k/year tax on all worldwide income for non-doms (7 years). Also Impatriate regime: 70% income exemption for 5 years.
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Non-doms (high earners)"; impatriate regime for employees/self-employed
Premium_Insights: Italian Impatriate Regime: 70% income exemption for 5 years (90% in Southern Italy including Naples). Extremely attractive for high earners moving to southern Italy. €100k flat tax for ultra-high net worth. Italian bureaucracy remains complex. Best: hire an Italian commercialista (accountant).

Tax_Score: Excellent – same Greek exemption framework
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 50% income tax exemption for 7 years – same as Athens.
Premium_Insights: Same tax benefits as Athens at significantly lower cost of living. For same income, Thessaloniki gives better net lifestyle value. Smaller nomad community but tax advantages are identical.

Tax_Score: Excellent – same as Sofia
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Same Bulgarian 10% flat system.
Premium_Insights: Same 10% flat as Sofia at lower cost of living. Smaller city, less nomad infrastructure but strong arts scene. Best for nomads wanting Bulgarian tax efficiency in quieter environment.

Tax_Score: Excellent – NHR applies, Madeira has additional incentives
Tax_Benefits_Premium: NHR 20% flat. Madeira IFCM (International Business Centre) for companies: 5% corporate tax.
Premium_Insights: Madeira IFCM offers 5% corporate tax for international services companies until 2027. Combined with NHR personal rate: very efficient structure for business owners. Digital Nomad Village (Ponta do Sol) has government support infrastructure.

Tax_Score: Excellent – ZEC 4% corporate tax unique in EU
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Beckham Law 24% personal + ZEC (Zona Especial Canaria) 4% corporate tax for registered companies.
Special_Regime_Name: ZEC – Zona Especial Canaria + Beckham Law
Social_Security_Applicable: Yes – reduced under ZEC for qualifying companies
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Company owners, freelancers incorporating, remote employees
Premium_Insights: ZEC requires minimum investment and job creation but offers EU's lowest corporate tax at 4%. Combined with year-round 22°C climate = exceptional value. Best structure: personal Beckham Law + ZEC company. Must maintain physical presence and staff.

Tax_Score: Excellent – NHR applies
Tax_Benefits_Premium: NHR / NHR 2.0: 20% flat on qualifying income.
Premium_Insights: Same NHR framework as Lisbon/Porto at much lower cost of living. Most budget-efficient Portugal tax base.

Tax_Score: Excellent – same Romanian micro-enterprise
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Same Romanian 1% micro-enterprise tax.
Premium_Insights: Westernmost Romania – proximity to Hungary and Serbia. Same low tax. Lower cost than Bucharest/Cluj. Less nomad infrastructure but growing.

Tax_Score: Good – flat tax, low social contributions option
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 21% flat income tax. Paušálne výdavky (flat expense deduction) for self-employed: 60% of revenue deducted.
Premium_Insights: Similar to Czech system. 60% lump-sum expense deduction for self-employed brings effective rate very low. Close to Vienna (1hr train) allows lifestyle arbitrage. Good for EU company registration via simple Slovak s.r.o. (LLC).

Tax_Score: Excellent – 0% dividends and capital gains
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 0% tax on dividends. 0% tax on capital gains. 12.5% corporate tax – lowest in EU. Non-dom: 50% income exemption for 10 years.
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Company owners, investors, high earners – non-dom for those not previously resident
Premium_Insights: Cyprus has one of Europe's most attractive tax regimes for investors and company owners. Non-dom status exempts from SDC tax on dividends/interest for 17 years. 60-day tax residency rule (vs 183 elsewhere) for those who don't become resident elsewhere. Non-Schengen EU impacts travel.

Tax_Score: Moderate – 30% ruling brings rate to competitive level
Tax_Benefits_Premium: 30% Ruling: 30% of gross salary paid tax-free for 5 years. Effective rate ~34% for €80k income.
Employment_Type_Eligibility: Employees with Dutch employer, specific salary minimum
Premium_Insights: 30% ruling requires Dutch employer, recruited from 150km+ outside NL, minimum salary ~€46k/year (2024). ZZP (freelance sole trader) available for EU citizens without sponsor but no 30% ruling. Groningen is student/university city – good community, lower cost than Amsterdam. Best for: employed workers with Dutch employer.

Tax_Score: Poor – same Austrian tax, smaller city
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Same Austrian research/R&D credits. No special nomad regime.
Premium_Insights: Same as Vienna framework. Innsbruck's advantage is Alpine outdoor lifestyle vs business hub. Gewerbeschein for EU self-employed. Best for: lifestyle-first nomads who don't prioritize tax optimization and love mountains/skiing.

Tax_Score: Moderate – same Irish framework as Dublin
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Same 12.5% corporate and SARP as Dublin.
Premium_Insights: Same Irish tax framework as Dublin at lower cost. Apple's European HQ is in Cork creating strong corporate tech ecosystem. Best for: business owners using Irish corporate structure.

Tax_Score: Poor – same Danish framework as Copenhagen
Tax_Benefits_Premium: Same Forskerordningen 32.84% flat scheme.
Premium_Insights: Same as Copenhagen framework at lower cost. Second city – less competitive housing. Not nomad-friendly from tax/visa perspective for independents.
